subject: Re: [junit] fundamental questions on JUnit
msgSnippet: ... JUnit is a white box testing tool meant for the developers to write as they write their code.  Checking the test infected doc, for an example of the
messageBody:
> 1) JUnit seems to test "functions" that return a value. How will you
> test "procedures" that do work instead?
> (It is 'against the rules' to change the design of them to return
> values - a testing tool should not force code changes.)

JUnit is a white box testing tool meant for the developers to write as
they write their code. Checking the test infected doc, for an example
of the testing first methodology.

If QA were employing this tool, then you might be right about it being
'against the rules' to change the code you're testing. But JUnit
encourages refactoring for testing. Often times it removes any hard
coded assumptions and you'll end up designing your code better.

Procedures that do work may be tricky, especially if you can't change
the code your testing (see the hard coded assumptions problem presenting
itself?). If can change the code though, you *should* manipulate it to
allow you to test the state of the object in some manner. Believe me,
your code will be better for it.

> 2) How will you test procedures that are composed of several
> functions?

(Leaving this for someone else to answer.)

> 3) Can JUnit ever replace stepping thru with a debugger?

My question is can it ever replace all my print statements?
